title: How Shopify builds a high-intensity culture | Farhan Thawar (VP and Head of Eng)
key_insights: Choose the harder path because even if you fail, you learn more and work with smarter people than taking the easy route
Pair programming is the most underutilized management tool in engineering - two people on one computer write better code faster
Create intensity through weekly updates (GSD), six-week reviews, and regular check-ins rather than expanding work hours
Delete code regularly - Shopify has a 'Delete Code Club' and routinely removes millions of lines to improve maintainability
Think platform-first: build infrastructure that enables anyone to build features in one hour rather than building point solutions
Hire through job trials and internships rather than traditional interviews - work product over resume evaluation
Micromanagement isn't bad if it means pairing on problems rather than just checking status
Everything you know might be wrong - maintain beginner's mind and experiment constantly

guest_background.current_role: VP and Head of Engineering at Shopify

topics_discussed: The philosophy of choosing harder paths for better outcomes
Being comfortable with looking stupid and asking dumb questions
Working with visionary leaders (billionaires) each decade
Creating organizational intensity through systems and cadence
Pair programming as a management and development tool
Weekly GSD (Get Shit Done) updates and six-week review cycles
Meeting Armageddon - deleting all recurring meetings annually
Moving from Slack to Facebook Workplace for announcements
Code deletion culture and simplification practices
Hiring philosophy focused on job trials over interviews
Internship program scaling to 1000 hires in 2025
Remote-first culture with intentional in-person experiences
Managing 120 direct reports through systems not meetings
Career failures including React Native decision at Shopify
memorable_quotes: Not everyone can look stupid in public over and over, but I believe it's my superpower
If you do the hard path and it doesn't work, actually you still win because you've now done something hard
Everyone says, 'Oh yeah, work hard and do more hours when you're young, whatever.' I'm like, 'What if you just did more per minute?'
frameworks_mentioned: Experiment vs Feature vs Infrastructure categorization
summary: Farhan Thawar shares Shopify's unique approach to building high-intensity engineering culture through pair programming, strategic meeting cadences, and choosing harder paths that lead to better long-term outcomes. He provides tactical advice on hiring, managing large teams, and creating systems that enable velocity without burning out people.
